column1: Arden-Arcade is a census-designated place (CDP) in Sacramento County
column2: California
column3: United States. The population was 92
column5: making it the second most populous census-designated place in California. It is east of the city of Sacramento and west of the community of Carmichael.

column1: Arden-Arcade is a principal locality of the Sacramento–Arden-Arcade–Roseville Metropolitan Statistical Area.
The history of the community of Arden-Arcade is documented in the "Sacramento ALC Historical Study 82"
column2: Rancho Del Paso
column3: Office of History
column6: California
column8: by Raymond Oliver. The first residents of what would become the Arden-Arcade area were the Nisenan of the Maidu tribe of Native Americans. The land was originally part of a Mexican land grant deeded to John Sutter
column9: the Rancho del Paso grant was negotiated from the Mexican governor by John Sutter on August 10
column10: 1843. Sutter then deeded the Rancho Del Paso to Eliab and Hiram Grimes and John Sinclair. Samuel Norris was the next owner of Rancho del Paso
column12: James Ben Ali Haggin managed the Rancho
column13: where he became known for breeding race horses. One of the horses bred on the Rancho
column15: won the 12th Kentucky Derby in world record time 1886. To ship his horses
column16: Haggin built a railroad spur from his northern paddocks (Approximately where today’s Hagginwood Golf Course is)
column17: toward the current day Union Pacific railroad tracks located northeast of the present-day Capitol City Freeway along the beginnings of Arcade Boulevard. On this site Haggin's staff built 24 barns with 64 stalls each plus some out buildings. It was here that he would ship his horses mostly to Kentucky
column18: some eventually shipping around the world.

column1: The name "Arden" may come from the Hebrew word for garden. But the most likely possibility is that Orlando Robertson

column1: Orlando Robertson was a land speculator who came to Sacramento after hearing about the exceptional lands of the Rancho Del Paso. He bought the Rancho in 1905 for $1.5 million for his Sacramento Colonization Company
column2: then laid out the streets and developed the tracts for sale. Robertson chose street names that reflected the inventors of the period
column3: Watt
column6: Bell and so on. By 1916
column7: and given the fertile soil and excellent supply of water
column8: Robertson was able to sell the tracts to farming families
column9: a large number of them newly off the boat Scandinavian immigrants. In fact the area around Gibbons Park was known as “Little Norway
column10: ” because of the many Norwegian families that settled there. Arden-Arcade and neighboring Carmichael were advertised as an excellent area for growing citrus
column12: nuts and stone fruit were also farmed here. At one time
column13: Arden-Arcade was the hop growing region of the world.

column1: Arden-Arcade's northern border is formed by Auburn Boulevard and Arcade Creek
column2: its southern border is primarily the American River
column3: its western border is Ethan Way and its eastern border is formed by Walnut Avenue

column1: Arden-Arcade is served by three major highways. Interstate 80 and the Capital City Freeway are just north of the community and just to the south of the American River (the community's southern border) is U.S. Route 50. Major east-west thoroughfares include El Camino Avenue
column2: Marconi Avenue
column3: Arden Way
column5: and Fair Oaks Boulevard. Major north-south thoroughfares include Fulton Avenue
column6: Watt Avenue

column1: Many of the major arterial streets that criss-cross through Arden-Arcade are named for the major inventors of the Industrial Revolution. It is assumed they were named around 1915 by Orlando Robertson
column2: the main property owner of the historic Rancho Del Paso at the time. The street names appear as the following in the archives immediately after this time.

column1: With a central location to many of the northeastern suburbs of Sacramento as well as the Sacramento region
column2: Arden-Arcade is a major shopping and commercial area. Fair Oaks Boulevard and Fulton Avenue are the major commercial corridors for Arden-Arcade. The Pavilions Shopping Center lies at this intersection
column3: and is anchored by a Williams-Sonoma and a Ruth's Chris Steakhouse. Loehmann's Plaza
column5: is also located along this corridor. Further north on Fulton Avenue near the Del Paso Country Club is Town & Country Village. The Village was the first shopping center west of the Mississippi River. Built and opened by Jere Strezik in 1949
column6: The Village was a high-end boutique center with an old west decor. In its heyday
column9: and elegant dining. It is located at Fulton and Marconi Avenue
column10: and today has Trader Joe's and Sprouts Farmers Market as main anchors. In 2012
column11: an Orange County developer bought it and tore down many of the structures at the original center and built new larger stores that now house Ross and TJ Maxx.

column1: Country Club Plaza is an indoor shopping mall located in Arden-Arcade. It is anchored by WinCo Foods. A new theater is being built and restaurants are due to open soon. The Plaza opened on November 19
column3: with a Stop and Shop market
column5: Woolworth and a Weinstock's Lubin department store. The Weinstock's building was designed by Charles Luckman
column6: with imported Italian marble and hardwood flooring from Kentucky.Car dealers are another major shopping attraction in the Arden-Arcade area. Despite competition from auto malls in Folsom
column9: Arden-Arcade has retained many high-end dealers that are unique to the Sacramento area. The epicenter of the auto business is on Fulton Avenue but some dealers have taken up on Auburn Boulevard so that they can be seen from the Capital City Freeway. Other dealers extend out as far west as Howe Avenue which is closer to the Arden Fair Mall. The Niello family's Niello Auto Group owns many of the car dealers in this area including Audi
column15: and Volkswagen. Von Housen owns the Mercedes Benz dealer at Howe Avenue and Alta Arden Expressway. Smart Cars are also sold on the same site. Kuni sells Buick
column18: and GM on the same site on Fulton Avenue. Turner Volvo is located on Arden Way between Fulton Avenue and Howe Avenue. Mel Rapton Honda is located on the main Fulton corridor. Harrold Ford is located on Howe Avenue near Arden Way. Maita sells Hyundais
column21: and Toyotas. Lexus of Sacramento and Sacramento Kia are also located along Fulton Avenue.

column1: Del Paso Country Club is a private country club located within Arden-Arcade. The club was founded in 1916 on land sold to the early members by Orlando Robertson in 1916. He offered a low interest rate and $8000 to build their clubhouse with. Membership is by invitation. The club includes a newly renovated 18-hole golf course
column2: a state-of-the-art fitness center and other facilities. The golf course hosted the 2015 Senior Open Golf Tournament.

column1: A new California governor's mansion built for Ronald Reagan was in Arden-Arcade in 1984 and was sold in 2004 and is a private residence. Governors George Deukmejian
column2: Pete Wilson
column3: and Gray Davis each occupied the house on Lake Wilhaggin Drive in the Wilhaggin area. The house was sold in 2004 after Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger decided not to live there and instead occupied the penthouse at the Hyatt Hotel in Downtown Sacramento when he did not commute back to Brentwood
area residents voted on Measure D.[1] The measure was defeated by a margin of 76% to 24%. If approved
column4: the area bounded by Auburn Boulevard on the north
column6: Ethan Way on the west
column7: and Mission Avenue/Jacob Lane on the east would have become the City of Arden-Arcade.

column1: The city would have been governed by a council-manager form of government.  Twenty-two candidates ran for the seven-member city council. If Measure D passed
column2: seven would have become city council members and the top vote-getter would have become mayor. A city manager would have been hired by the council to implement goals
column3: policies and ordinances approved by the city council. The defeat of Measure D rendered the results of the election a moot point.

column1: According to the fiscal analysis [2] completed under the auspices of the Sacramento Local Area Formation Commission (LAFCo)
column2: the city as proposed “may be fiscally feasible” (p. 7). LAFCo assesses the feasibility of a new city according to three standards: it is likely to be feasible; it is not likely; or it may be feasible.  The financials for the proposed new city were not strong enough to warrant finding the proposed new city likely to be feasible.

column1: The fiscal analysis includes “revenue neutrality payments” that the city must pay Sacramento County to be in compliance with California Code section 56815.  City taxpayers would be required to reimburse Sacramento County over $6 million a year
column2: and $219 million over a 35-year period for loss of sales tax revenue.
the new local government would have cost $37 million each year by year 10 of the analysis (Table E.3). At that point

column5: 600 on general fund expenses for the city manager's office
column6: attorney services
column10: etc. Road maintenance expenses are expected to cost $4

column1: Proponents claimed that the new city would have improved services and created community pride in the City of Arden-Arcade without any new taxes.  Opponents believed that revenue assumptions were risky and
column2: if wrong
column3: could lead to higher taxes.

column1: Revenues would have largely come from property taxes and sales taxes.  [5] LAFCo's projections of property taxes are based on this assumption about area property values: “The fiscal model assumes a nominal annual property appreciation rate of 5.2% excluding the additional value from new development” (p. 45). Property sales and retail sales are closely tied to the unemployment rate
column2: and Sacramento ranks 326 out of 372 cities according to the most recent information available from the US Bureau of Labor Statistics.[6]

column3: the City of Sacramento posted on their website that they have no plans to annex Arden-Arcade.[7]. Only the Local Area Formation Commission (LAFCo) has the regulatory authority under state law to approve or disapprove of the annexation of territory by a city (Cortese-Knox-Hertzberg Act of 2000
column4: California Government Code Section 56000). LAFCo requires cities to keep up their general plan and look at overlapping jurisdictions. In that context
column5: the City of Sacramento has collected information about Arden-Arcade but has not taken any steps toward incorporation
column6: the first of which would be identifying Arden-Arcade as within its sphere of influence.

column1: Incorporation proponents have repeatedly claimed that the city could take over the area in as little as six months with no opportunity for residents to vote. The City of Sacramento's process includes a dozen steps that would conservatively take three to five years to go through the lengthy and expensive process required. The most recent piece of land to be annexed was several hundred acres of fallow agricultural land
column2: Greenbriar.[8] The process took four years for this small
column3: non-controversial annexation at the request of the developer after four rounds of Environmental Impact Reviews
column6: finance plan

column1: As the city describes on its website
column2: residents of an area may request annexation
column3: or the city may investigate it. "With inhabited areas
column4: annexation must also be supported by a majority of voters within the area proposed for annexation."[9]

column1: If the city undertook the lengthy road toward annexation and ultimately voted to approve
column2: it would then have to file an application with the Local Agency Formation Commission. The  many factors that LAFCo considers [10] when reviewing applications are listed in detail on its website as are its powers and authority.[11]. It includes the opportunity for public testimony.

column1: The City of Sacramento's last annexation of an inhabited area
column2: College Greens
column3: was in the late 1950s. While it discussed interest in Arden-Arcade in the 1960s
column4: the City of Sacramento did not initiate formal steps toward incorporation.

column1: In its analysis of the area as part of its general plan update

column5: p. 3-AA-5 at http://www.sacgp.org/). The city has also noted that the area has significant infrastructure needs and the likelihood of community opposition to incorporation.

column1: The Arden-Arcade Community Planning Council is a nine-member council that helps make decisions for the community of Arden-Arcade. These nine members are appointed by the Sacramento County Board of Supervisors.

column2: Greater Arden Chamber of Commerce
column3: and Metro Chamber Arden Arcade Council all serve the business community of Arden-Arcade.
